text:
IN THE CROWN COURT AT NORTHAMPTON
R v. Mr H
Case No. N2026/09734
Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge S. M. KELLY
Filed: 25 September 2026

Mr H stands before this court for sentence having pleaded guilty to two counts: firstly, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and, secondly, possession of material likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism, contrary to section 58 of the same Act. The matters relate to a period stretching from late November 2024 through to his arrest in April 2026, and involve a complexity and level of persistence which bear directly on the issue of risk and public safety.

The procedural chronology in this matter has not been straightforward, nor has it been expeditious. Arrested on 18 April 2026 at precisely 07:53, pursuant to warrants issued under section 43C of the Terrorism Act 2000, Mr H was first brought before the South Midlands Magistrates’ Court before being committed to this jurisdiction. At the initial remand hearing, there was debate as to the sufficiency of evidence disclosed—a procedural quagmire exacerbated by delays arising from specialist digital forensic analysis required by the National Digital Exploitation Laboratory (NDEL). It is necessary, even at this early stage, to acknowledge the resource demands such cases place upon both the Crown Prosecution Service Counter-Terrorism Division and their agency partners.

That burden is by no means trivial. As set out in the Crown’s submission, there were seventeen devices recovered from Mr H’s residence, including three encrypted mobile telephones, two laptops employing BitLocker, and an external drive bearing post-it notes referencing various open-source software ciphers. Processing delays arose not simply from volume but from the use of rare cryptographic protocols; the defence have suggested prejudice, though their access to rolling disclosure updates was, in my judgment, both timely and sufficient to protect fairness in these proceedings.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_1}

The origins of the investigation into Mr H trace back to an anonymous Prevent referral made by a university librarian in December 2024. The librarian in question, whose letter has been read into the record, observed Mr H repeatedly reserving works related to counterinsurgency tactics and explosive chemistry—texts, as she noted, not unknown in academic settings but conspicuous for their frequency and for Mr H’s insistence upon private study carrels. The matter was at first triaged under the Channel process but, given the absence of overt risk behaviour at that stage, was shelved. I make no criticism of the initial response but note, as does the regional Channel panel, the inherent limitation in pre-emptive intervention strategies absent clear thresholds for information sharing across professional boundaries.

In considering the management of risk, it is worth recording that it has become routine for the courts to receive assurances as to the seamless nature of “integrated multi-agency responses” in the counter-terror sphere. The court is, to a degree, sceptical of claims to perfect integration. The MAPPA (Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements) framework, under which Mr H was flagged for Category 3 discussions, did convene in a timely fashion in this case—though I acknowledge the persistence of local authority partners, who pressed for formal risk assessment even when police intelligence was classified at the “Not for Sharing” level.

In assessing the mitigation advanced by Mr Pryce, representing Mr H, it is perhaps instructive to note his observations on Mr H’s familial background. The defence placed before the court references penned by Mr H’s mother and his older brother, each attesting to what they called his “capacity for care” demonstrated through regular volunteering at a city soup kitchen. Such observations are, of course, welcomed as evidence of pro-social behaviour; but their capacity to bear weight in the face of deeply antisocial criminal intent is, in reality, highly limited. The court cannot, and does not, disregard the social context in which terrorism arises, but neither can it allow gestures of decency to obscure the gravity of offending.

The court records that Mr H appeared under representation from Mr Pryce, appointed under a Legal Aid Representation Order approved only after several administrative obstacles occasioned by the Legal Aid Agency’s ongoing resource review. Delays in approving funding for necessary psychiatric evaluation unfortunately further postponed these proceedings. The consequence has been not only undue delay to the administration of justice, but also additional strain upon the defendant, witnesses, and the investigative team. The fault for such delay, I record for the avoidance of doubt, lies at the institutional rather than the individual level: it is a persistent reality in this jurisdiction that representations to the Agency require repeated follow-up and often, when answered at last, rest on narrow constructions of statutory funding guidance with little appreciation for the realities of complex crime.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_2}

The matter was first listed for trial on 12 July 2026; however, due to the non-availability of an appropriately security-cleared jury pool, the hearing was adjourned. It is a fact—not infrequently lamented—that the listing constraints endemic to this court’s aging infrastructure, compounded by extended criminal bar industrial action, have placed acute pressure on the administration of complex terrorism cases. In this case, the defendant remained on remand at the South Midlands Terrorism Holding Unit during the adjournment, with full credit to be given for time served. The operational challenges in providing video link facilities—owing to a water leak in Courtroom 5 and the need to relocate bail applications to an adjoining district court—were met with notable resourcefulness by the court managers and court ushers, to whom I extend my appreciation.

The sentencing exercise in terrorism matters is distinct from many other areas of criminal law, and in that regard the current case is no exception. Section 5 of the Terrorism Act carries a maximum of life imprisonment. The 2024 Sentencing Guidelines, following the five-judge decision in R v. Khedira [2025] EWCA Crim 229, establish that even preparatory conduct interrupted well before any direct physical harm can warrant a sentence approaching the statutory maximum, where the aggravating features are sufficiently grave.

Parliament has repeatedly made clear, not least through the Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures Act 2011, its intent that courts treat the protection of the public as paramount in the sentencing calculus for terrorism offences. In that respect, the remarks of Lord Justice Renwick in R v. Vassiliev [2023] EWCA Crim 161—though given in the context of an online propaganda case—remain highly relevant: “Where preparation is sophisticated, persistent, and ideologically driven, and where rehabilitative prospects are at best speculative, the primary functions of sentence are deterrence and incapacitation.”

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_3}

Counsel for Mr H has submitted that, despite the late pleas entered on 12 September 2026, full sentencing discount ought to be applied under the principles established in R v. Calvert [2020] EWCA Crim 1244. The court cannot accept that contention. As explained in R v. Knightley [2023] EWCA Crim 308, a plea is only entitled to full one-third credit when made at the earliest opportunity in the proceedings. Where, as here, the defendant maintained a not guilty stance until after the close of prosecution service of digital evidence schedules and pre-trial legal argument, the benefit is inherently limited.

The rise in late pleas in the Crown Court—especially in cases involving complex digital evidence—has been a persistent headache for both courts and victims. Counsel frequently cite the need for disclosure to be complete before advising a plea; yet late pleas, entered solely after the defendant is exposed to the totality of the Crown’s case, avail little either to witnesses or to the interests of procedural economy. It is not, as it is sometimes portrayed, a symptom solely of legal gamesmanship; it is, more often, a function of an overburdened system struggling to provide timely access to evidence, rooted in chronic under-resourcing of modern forensic capacity.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_4}

The neutral expert report from Dr Rowan Bland, consultant forensic psychiatrist, goes to the question of culpability rather than dangerousness. Dr Bland concludes that Mr H demonstrates “rigid cognitive style and an acute susceptibility to online grievance narratives,” but offers no diagnosis of mental disorder. There is no history, within the records or collateral reports, of psychosis, affective disturbance, or personality disorder rising to the threshold of diminished responsibility. Dr Bland further remarks—echoing the position taken in the National Offender Management Service’s 2025 thematic review—that “ideological fixity and cognitive closure” are recurrent features in defendants convicted of contemporary terrorism offences.

It is instructive, in this context, to revisit the decision in R v. Faulk [2024] EWCA Crim 435. There, the defendant, a 33-year-old engineer, advanced the argument that his autistic spectrum disorder and intense focus upon political grievances ought to mitigate the necessary intent. The Court of Appeal was clear in its response: “Focused, even obsessive, interest in politics or technologies relevant to violence does not absolve a defendant from culpability where he acts with knowledge and intent.” That case concerned the construction of an incendiary device resembling a homemade flame-thrower stored within a suburban garage; nonetheless, its principles as to mental state are instructive here. For the avoidance of doubt, there is no suggestion that Mr H’s conduct mirrors the technical features of that offending.

Though the analogy is tempting, I make clear that no direct comparison is warranted between the facts of Faulk and those of the instant case. The sentencing exercise is always an individual one. In this vein, let it not be said that the present defendant is to be sentenced for conduct not his own, nor that the specific risks of his actions are to be diluted by reference to technical similarities with the conduct of others.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_5}

The court takes this occasion to commend, formally and on the record, the staff of the East Midlands Deradicalisation Project, led by Mr Anthony Quayle and Dr Nisha Saoirse. Their correspondence to the court was notable for its restraint and clarity. Despite their limited funding and the atmosphere of suspicion which too often attends their efforts, the project’s attempts to re-engage Mr H in structured psychological intervention have been persistent and entirely professional. That their work continues under the shadow of repeated online threats is testament to the seriousness with which they approach what is, frankly, a thankless and periodically dangerous task.

Similarly, recognition must be given to the Northampton Probation Service’s Terrorism Management Team, and in particular to Mr Sajid Brunning, whose pre-sentence report is both lucid and forthright. Mr Brunning rightly notes the gaps in the statutory support architecture, drawing attention to the fact that—owing to a spike in high-risk licensees—the team’s regular caseload now exceeds the capacity modelled during the initial commissioning phase by 42%. That this workload is maintained with only one clinical psychologist in post, against a notional establishment of three, does not escape the court’s notice.

It is equally relevant to note that Mr H’s attempts to access employment post-release remain speculative at best. His prior work history in data cabling for a local IT installation firm was terminated in January 2025 following breaches of internal cyber-security protocols. Though the defence have sought to rely on letters from a local model railway society attesting to his skill in miniature electrics as character evidence, I find these to be of negligible weight, offering no realistic prospect of future stability absent effective risk management.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_6}

A further persistent difficulty facing this court—and indeed, courts nationwide—is the challenge of digital disclosure. In this case, the relevant exhibits scheduled for review by the Crown Prosecution Service Digital Team exceeded 1.2 terabytes. Under the much-discussed “Disclosure by Default” pilot, that volume is no longer unusual. The process demanded not only the use of stand-alone air-gapped analysis terminals, but also, due to malfunction of the primary NDEL secure server, the physical transportation of three encrypted external drives by secure courier from Northampton to the regional laboratory in Peterborough. That the chain of custody in each instance was meticulously maintained speaks to the diligence of both police and Crown, but it remains a grim reflection of the inadequacy of the system’s resourcing that logistical issues of this nature persist in the third decade of the twenty-first century.

The pre-sentence report, dated 18 September 2026, adapts the National Offender Management Service OASys Terrorism Screening Tool for risk assessment. Mr Brunning’s conclusions are unambiguous: Mr H “poses a high risk of serious harm to members of the public arising from ideologically-driven hostile action, with specific risk elevation linked to access to unsupervised online spaces and unmonitored financial instruments.” The report recommends, in the event of eventual release, a combination of high-intensity supervision requirements, a suitably restrictive license imposing exclusions relating to electronic communication, mandatory engagement in deradicalisation programming, and regular reviews under MAPPA Category 3 arrangements. I direct that these recommendations be incorporated as applicable into any subsequent sentencing order.

Of tangential but revealing import, I note the submissions of the defence seeking to rely upon the decision in R v. Jessen [2022] EWCA Crim 891, a warehouse arson case in Suffolk. There, the court held that the “exceptional personal mitigation” occasioned by an unanticipated bereavement and attendant breakdown justified a marked departure from the Sentencing Guidelines in an arson that levelled a commercial warehouse, causing £1.2 million in uninsured losses and temporarily displacing ten employees. Jessen’s circumstances, it was said, were genuinely tragic, and his relapse into offending bespoke genuine distress. I find the analogy to be inapposite; the elements which justified downward movement in Jessen—acute distress and absence of planning—are wholly lacking in the instant matter. There is here neither suddenness nor impulsivity, but a sustained, calculated willingness to pursue ideological aims through proscribed conduct.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_7}

In addressing the proper regulatory regime, I must also carefully consider the scope of any ancillary orders. The Crown asks that an extended license period be appended, to facilitate sustained risk monitoring post-discharge. Given the findings of the probation report and the requirements of Schedule 21A of the Sentencing Act 2020—requiring the imposition of terrorism notification requirements where the risk threshold is crossed—I am satisfied such ancillary supervision will be necessary. I am also asked to authorise the imposition of a Serious Crime Prevention Order and an indefinite Terrorism Notification Order as adjuncts to primary sentence. A final decision will, appropriately, await the completion of the pre-sentence custodial risk assessment.

It must be noted that from the moment of his arrest, Mr H engaged neither with the Deradicalisation Project’s outreach workers nor with the Prevent-linked resettlement mentors. Whilst the defence submits that engagement was not realistically possible on remand, and that refusal to participate in interventions does not amount to aggravation, I find the absence of any proactive willingness to engage troubling, especially given the degree and duration of the offending. The court has limited means to compel engagement, but is obliged under section 45 of the Counter-Terrorism and Sentencing Act 2021 to take post-conviction disengagement into account as a risk factor in community placement planning.

In the consideration of risk management, the observations of the Court in R v. Kelly [2022] EWCA Crim 436, concerning the persistent risk posed by those convicted under section 5 who acquire digital expertise in custody, are instructive. The court there remarked upon the “ease with which technical knowledge acquired in pursuit of criminal ends may be redeployed post-release unless vigilant monitoring is implemented.” The case does not, of course, establish any general presumption, but it underscores the systemic challenge of identifying and managing residual risk in offenders whose skills are portable, replicable, and not reliably extinguished by punitive intervention.

The court is also mindful of the wider social and political context in which ideology-driven criminality flourishes. Community confidence in public protection mechanisms stands at a critical juncture, worn by visible gaps in service provision and the increasingly strident rhetoric in sections of the media and political class. The responsibility upon the court is, now more than ever, to approach sentencing decisions in terrorism not merely as acts of retribution but as principled exercises in public safeguarding. As noted in the introduction to the 2024 Sentencing Guidelines, every decision must be “transparent, proportionate, and necessary,” recognising the balancing of risks within an imperfect and under-resourced system.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_8}

I therefore direct that a full pre-sentence report be prepared, to address not only the core risk and rehabilitation issues arising but also to explore the viability of bespoke monitoring conditions and pathways to structured disengagement from extremist ideology. The probation service shall consider the possible imposition of a High-Intensity Supervision Order, the suitability of DDP referral, and any requirement for additional technology restrictions. The report should discuss the feasibility of approved premises placements, options for psychological input using the Structured Professional Judgement model, and an extended period of licence supervision, with particular attention to residual digital risk. No sentencing decision will be made until receipt of the full report, any additional documentary submissions, and further psychiatric opinion as, and if, required.

These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 25 September 2026, in Court 2 at the Crown Court at Northampton. Proceedings have been transcribed and will be recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and any sentence imposed will be sent to the statutory authorities for registration. Costs are reserved. The period for any appeal will run from the date of sentence under the Criminal Appeal Act 1968.

These are the orders of the court.
